parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Adding either compost or manure resulted in higher organic matter content.
[Statement 2]: Adding either compost or manure resulted in larger soil aggregations.
[Statement 3]: The application of either manure or compost resulted in higher crop yields.
[Statement 4]: Studies have shown varied outcomes when focusing on manure.
[Statement 5]: Manure application can cause an increase in soil organic matter.
[Statement 6]: Some studies found no change in soil organic matter with manure application.
[Statement 7]: Manure application can increase nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium levels in soil.
[Statement 8]: Some studies observed no significant differences in nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium levels after manure application.
[Statement 9]: Manure was found to improve soil stability.
[Statement 10]: Manure was found to reduce erosion.
[Statement 11]: The application of manure was associated with higher emissions of carbon dioxide.
[Statement 12]: The application of manure was associated with higher emissions of nitrous oxide.
[Statement 13]: The application of either manure or compost can cause an increase in microbial biomass.
[Statement 14]: The application of manure is associated with higher carbon levels in the soil.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__To improve soil fertility, how does adding compost compare to adding manure?
_gemini-2-5-pro__What are the potential negative impacts of using no-tillage systems in arable fields in a Mediterranean climate?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In a Mediterranean climate, some studies have found that no-tillage systems can have negative impacts on crop yields.
[Statement 2]: In a Mediterranean climate, some studies have found that no-tillage systems can have negative impacts on the environment.
[Statement 3]: In some comparisons, no-tillage has been associated with lower yields of cereals, fruits and vegetables, and sunflower seeds.
[Statement 4]: Reduced tillage has been found in some studies to result in less nitrogen in the soil.
[Statement 5]: Reduced tillage has been found in some studies to result in reduced microbial biomass.
[Statement 6]: Other negative impacts observed in some studies include lower water-stability of soil aggregates.
[Statement 7]: Other negative impacts observed in some studies include smaller soil aggregates.
[Statement 8]: Other negative impacts observed in some studies include increased emissions of carbon dioxide and nitrous oxide from the soil.
[Statement 9]: One study found that shallower tillage led to more soil erosion.
[Statement 10]: In one study in Spain, lower straw yields were found in plots with no tillage compared to reduced tillage.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__For arable fields in the Mediterranean, how does a no-tillage system compare with a reduced tillage system for improving soil health?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A meta-analysis covering multiple Mediterranean countries indicated that reduced tillage resulted in higher organic matter in soils when compared to conventional tillage.
[Statement 2]: Studies in Italy, Spain, Syria, and the USA found increased organic matter in soils with reduced tillage compared to conventional tillage.
[Statement 3]: Two studies found similar levels of organic matter in soils with reduced tillage compared to conventional tillage.
[Statement 4]: Eleven studies in Italy, Spain, and the USA observed more microbial biomass in soils with reduced tillage versus conventional tillage.
[Statement 5]: The impact of reduced tillage on soil nutrients like nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium showed mixed results compared to conventional tillage.
[Statement 6]: Some studies on reduced tillage reported increases in soil nutrients like nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium, while some reported decreases, and others found no significant difference compared to conventional tillage.
[Statement 7]: For no-tillage systems, nine controlled studies in Spain and the USA found a greater amount of water in the soil compared to tilled soils.
[Statement 8]: One study in Spain noted that barley used water more efficiently in no-tillage plots.
[Statement 9]: There were no studies found concerning pathogens, pesticides, nutrients or sediments for no-tillage systems.

[Statement 1]: Planting ground cover in Mediterranean orchards or vineyards can potentially lead to reduced nitrogen levels in the soil.
[Statement 2]: Planting ground cover in Mediterranean orchards or vineyards can potentially lead to reduced phosphorus levels in the soil.
[Statement 3]: One study in the USA found less nitrogen in soils with ground cover in some comparisons.
[Statement 4]: Two studies in Spain and the USA found less phosphorus in soils with seeded cover crops compared to tilled soils in some instances.
[Statement 5]: The presence of cover crops can lead to lower pH levels in the soil.
[Statement 6]: The presence of cover crops can lead to increased emissions of carbon dioxide from the soil.
[Statement 7]: The presence of cover crops can lead to increased emissions of nitrous oxide from the soil.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the potential drawbacks for crop production when planting ground cover in Mediterranean orchards or vineyards?
_gemini-2-5-pro__What does the evidence say about how adding different organic amendments to soil affects greenhouse gas emissions on Mediterranean farmland?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Two studies in Spain found higher carbon dioxide emissions when slurry is added to the soil.
[Statement 2]: One study in Spain showed no difference in carbon dioxide emissions when slurry is added to the soil.
[Statement 3]: One study in Spain indicated that less methane was absorbed by soils with added slurry.
[Statement 4]: Three studies in Spain found similar methane fluxes in soils with added slurry compared to soils without added slurry.
[Statement 5]: Five studies in Spain reported higher nitrous oxide emissions in soils with added slurry.
[Statement 6]: One study in Spain found similar nitrous oxide emissions in soils with added slurry compared to soils without added slurry.
[Statement 7]: A Spanish study found similar nitrous oxide emissions when comparing digested and untreated slurry.
[Statement 8]: Another Spanish study found similar carbon dioxide and methane emissions when comparing digested and untreated slurry.
[Statement 9]: Four studies in Italy and Spain noted higher carbon dioxide emissions from plots with organic fertilizer compared to plots with inorganic fertilizers.
[Statement 10]: One Spanish study found similar carbon dioxide emissions between plots with organic fertilizer and plots with inorganic fertilizers.
[Statement 11]: Two Spanish studies revealed that more methane was absorbed by soils with organic fertilizer compared to soils with inorganic fertilizer.
[Statement 12]: Two other Spanish studies showed similar methane absorption amounts in soils with organic fertilizer compared to soils with inorganic fertilizer.
[Statement 13]: Three studies, including a meta-analysis, reported lower nitrous oxide emissions from plots with organic fertilizer compared to plots with inorganic fertilizer.
[Statement 14]: Five studies in Spain found similar nitrous oxide emissions from plots with organic fertilizer compared to plots with inorganic fertilizer.
[Statement 15]: A meta-analysis indicated lower nitrous oxide emissions after adding solid organic fertilizer, but not liquid organic fertilizer, compared to inorganic fertilizer.
[Statement 16]: One study in Spain found that plots with slurry absorbed methane, while plots with manure emitted methane.
[Statement 17]: One study in Spain found more carbon dioxide in the soil of ungrazed plots compared to grazed plots.
[Statement 18]: A US study found similar amounts of carbon dioxide in the soil of ungrazed plots compared to grazed plots.
[Statement 19]: A study in the USA found less methane in the soils of ungrazed plots compared to cattle-grazed plots.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the effects of different soil amendments on soil organisms in Mediterranean farmland?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A controlled, randomized, replicated trial in Italy discovered that the application of a high dosage of compost resulted in an elevation of microbial biomass.
[Statement 2]: In five controlled trials in China and India, as well as a study in Japan, soils treated with a combination of manure and inorganic fertilizers showed increased microbial biomass.
[Statement 3]: In five controlled trials in China and India, as well as a study in Japan, soils treated with a combination of manure and inorganic fertilizers showed increased microbial activity.
[Statement 4]: An increase in microbial diversity was noted in a trial where soils were treated with a combination of manure and inorganic fertilizers.

[Statement 1]: The action "Manage natural water bodies in arid areas to prevent desiccation" is a suggested practice.
[Statement 2]: No studies were found to evaluate the effects of managing natural water bodies in arid areas to prevent desiccation.
[Statement 3]: Providing buffer strips alongside water courses can positively influence biodiversity.
[Statement 4]: Growing cover crops can reduce weeds.
[Statement 5]: Taking field corners out of management has been linked to higher grey partridge survival.
[Statement 6]: Reducing field size can increase butterfly and burnet moth populations.
[Statement 7]: Converting to organic farming may boost the richness and abundance of butterflies and moths.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__To improve water availability on my arable farm in a Mediterranean climate, what management practices can I use?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Three studies investigated the effects of planting or maintaining hedgerows on farmland.
[Statement 2]: Two studies investigating the effects of planting or maintaining hedgerows on farmland were conducted in the UK and one was conducted in Switzerland.
[Statement 3]: A replicated, site comparison study in the UK and Switzerland found that retaining and enhancing hedgerows and other field boundary features was associated with higher brown hare density in arable sites.
[Statement 4]: A replicated, site comparison study in the UK and Switzerland found that retaining and enhancing hedgerows and other field boundary features was not associated with higher brown hare density in grassland sites.
[Statement 5]: A replicated, site comparison study in the UK found that establishing hedgerows alongside arable land increased small mammal abundance.
[Statement 6]: A study found that Irish hare numbers did not increase.
[Statement 7]: A replicated site comparison study in the USA found similar amounts of water in soils in restored and remnant riparian habitats.
[Statement 8]: A replicated site comparison study from the USA found more weeds in orchards next to restored riparian habitats compared to remnant habitats.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__How do habitat creation actions, such as planting hedgerows or restoring watercourses, impact biodiversity on Mediterranean farmland?
_gemini-2-5-pro__How do additions of compost, manure, and slurry compare in their effects on soil organic matter and nutrients in Mediterranean farmland?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A study in Turkey found that applying both manure and compost increased soil organic matter.
[Statement 2]: A study in Turkey found that applying both manure and compost improved soil structure.
[Statement 3]: Adding slurry had mixed effects on soil organic matter.
[Statement 4]: One study in Spain noted an increase in organic matter with slurry application in some instances.
[Statement 5]: Three other studies across Spain and multiple Mediterranean countries found no significant change in soil organic matter with slurry application.
[Statement 6]: In three studies conducted in Canada, Spain, the UK, and the USA, the application of farmyard or poultry manure was found to decrease nutrient loss.
[Statement 7]: In three studies conducted in Canada, Spain, the UK, and the USA, the application of farmyard or poultry manure was found to increase nitrogen levels.
[Statement 8]: One study indicated that applying farmyard manure in winter was more effective at reducing nutrient loss than applying poultry manure or slurry in autumn.
[Statement 9]: Another study showed that manure application could lead to higher nitrate leaching.
[Statement 10]: The effects of slurry on soil nutrients were varied.
[Statement 11]: Two studies in Spain reported higher nitrate concentrations in soils with added slurry.
[Statement 12]: Two other studies in Portugal and Spain found no significant difference in nitrate concentrations in soils with added slurry.
[Statement 13]: One study in Spain found an increase in ammonium levels with slurry application.
[Statement 14]: Another study in Spain did not observe an increase in ammonium levels with slurry application.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the effects of excluding grazing animals on plant biodiversity in grasslands and shrublands in Mediterranean climates?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Four of eight studies that looked at the effects of excluding livestock found an increase in the biomass, species richness, density and cover of understory plants.
[Statement 2]: Four of eight studies that looked at the effects of excluding livestock found mixed or no effect on understory plants.
[Statement 3]: Three of four studies found that excluding livestock increased the size and density of regenerating trees.
[Statement 4]: In freshwater marshes in Morocco, the exclusion of livestock had varied effects.
[Statement 5]: One study found that after more than 30 years of livestock exclusion, plant species richness was similar to grazed areas in a dry year.
[Statement 6]: One study found that after more than 30 years of livestock exclusion, plant species richness was greater than in grazed areas in a wet year.
[Statement 7]: In one study, the number of wetland-characteristic plant species was similar between areas with livestock excluded and grazed areas.
[Statement 8]: In the same study, the overall abundance of wetland-characteristic plant species was greater in the excluded areas.
[Statement 9]: Other studies in Morocco showed that marshes with livestock excluded had a different overall plant community.
[Statement 10]: Other studies in Morocco showed that overall plant species richness in marshes with livestock excluded was typically similar to grazed sites.
